sen.j: 石田 正継（いしだ まさつぐ、生年不詳 - 慶長5年9月17日 (旧暦)（1600年10月23日））は、安土桃山時代の戦国武将。
sen.e: Masatsugu ISHIDA (birth date unknown - October 23, 1600) was the busho (Japanese military commander) in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Masatsugu ISHIDA (birth date unknown - October 23, 1600) was a busho (Japanese military commander) of the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Masatsugu ISHIDA (birth date unknown - October 23, 1600) was a busho (Japanese military commander) of the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.j: 父は石田為広（陸奥守仲成？清心？為厚？）といわれるが不明。
sen.e: His father is said to be Tamehiro ISHIDA (Mutsu-no-kami (Lord of Mutsu Province) Nakanari? Kiyomune? Tameatsu?) but uncertain.
His father is said to have been Tamehiro (or maybe Nakanari, the Kami (Lord) of Mutsu Province; Kiyomune; or Tameatsu) but this is uncertain.
His father is said to have been Tamehiro (or maybe Nakanari, the Lord of Mutsu Province; Kiyomune; or Tameatsu) but this is uncertain.

sen.j: 子に石田正澄、石田三成などがいる。
sen.e: His children include Masazumi ISHIDA and Mitsunari ISHIDA.
His children included Masazumi ISHIDA and Mitsunari ISHIDA.
His children included Masazumi ISHIDA and Mitsunari ISHIDA.

sen.j: 左悟右衛門・藤右衛門・太郎右衛門。
sen.e: His alias were Sagoemon, Touemon, Tarouemon.
sen.cmt: 左悟右衛門→Sagoemonと判断しました[定訳不明]
sen.e: His was also known as Sagoemon, Touemon, Tarouemon.
His was also known as Sagoemon, Toemon, Taroemon.
His rank was Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, Oki-no-kami (Lord of Oki Province).
His was a member of the Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade and the Kami (Lord) of Oki Province.
sen.cmt: rank was'→'was a member of the'Added 'and the'Deleted 'Oki-no-kami'
sen.e: His was a member of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and Oki no kami (Governor of Oki Province).
sen.cmt: 用語集より、従五位下→Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)隠岐守→Oki no kami (Governor of Oki Province)

sen.j: 「正継」は三成出世後の名乗りであり、それ以前は政成・為成・晴成など名乗っていたらしいが、何れもはっきりしない。
sen.e: "Masatsugu" was the name he was called by after his son Mitsunari succeeded in life, and was supposedly called as Masanari, Tamenari, or Harunari prior to it but remains uncertain.
Apparently originally called Masanari, Tamenari, or Harunari (though this is uncertain), "Masatsugu" was the name he used after his son, Mitsunari, became successful.
sen.cmt: Changed word order'Supposedly'→'Apparently originally''but remains uncertain'→'(though this is uncertain)''succeeded in life'→'became successful'
sen.e: Apparently originally called Masanari, Tamenari, or Harunari (though this is uncertain), 'Masatsugu' was the name he used after his son, Mitsunari, became successful.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 近江国坂田郡石田村（滋賀県長浜市石田町）の出身の地侍というが、京極氏の被官とする説もある。
sen.e: He was said to be ji-samurai (samurai who managed farms with peasants) from Ishida-mura (Ishida Village), Sakata-gun (Sakata District), Omi-no-kuni (Omi Province) (Ishida-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture), but there was also a theory that he was Hikan (samurai servant) of the Kyogoku clan.

He was said to be a ji-samurai (low-ranking farmer-samurai) from Ishida-mura, Sakata-gun, Omi-no-kuni (Omi Province) (present day Ishida-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture), but there is also a theory that he was Hikan (vassal) of the Kyogoku clan.
sen.cmt: Changed definitions of Ji-zamurai and Hikan―I don't think 'hikan' was confined to samurai.Added 'present day'
sen.e: He was said to be a ji-samurai (low-ranking farmer-samurai) from Ishida-mura, Sakata-gun, Omi-no-kuni (Omi Province) (present day Ishida-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture), but there is also a theory that he was Hikan (vassal) of the Kyogoku clan.

sen.j: 和歌や文学に造詣の深い才人であった。
sen.e: He had a profound knowledge for waka and literatures and excelled in those fields.
He had a profound knowledge of, and was very accomplished in, waka poetry and literature.
sen.cmt: for'→'of''excelled in those fields'→'was very accomplished in'
sen.e: He had a profound knowledge of, and was very accomplished in, waka poetry and literature.

sen.j: 子の三成が豊臣秀吉の家臣となるに及び、正継はとしてこれをよく補佐した。
sen.e: Once his son became the servant to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Masatsugu served as the magistrate and substituted for him.
After his son, Mitsunari, became a retainer of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Masatsugu often acted as his advisor.
sen.cmt: Once'→'after''servant'→'retainer''served as the magistrate and substituted for him'→'often acted as his advisor'
sen.e: After his son, Mitsunari, became a retainer of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Masatsugu often acted as his advisor.

sen.j: 三成が五奉行にまで出世し、佐和山城に封ぜられると、同時に正継も近江国内3万石の大名に取り立てられる（1595年）。
sen.e: Once Mitsunari was promoted to Go-bugyo (Five Commissioners) and lived in Sawayama-jo Castle, he became daimyo with 30,000 koku of Omi-no-kuni (1595).
When Mitsunari was promoted to the Go-bugyo (Five Commissioners) and transferred to Sawayama-jo Castle, Masatsugu was made, in 1595, a daimyo worth 30,000 koku in Omi-no-kuni.
When Mitsunari was promoted to the Go-bugyo (Five Commissioners) and transferred to Sawayama-jo Castle, Masatsugu was made, in 1595, a daimyo worth 30,000 koku in Omi Province.

sen.j: 以後は城代として、三成留守時の庶政を掌る。
sen.e: He ruled as Jodai (the keeper of castle) and controlled shosei (politics) while Mitsunari was absent.
As the Jodai, or castle caretaker, he was in charge of political affairs whenever Mitsunari was away.
sen.cmt: Changed definition of Jodai.Deleted 'shosei'Deleted 'He ruled''controlled '→'in charge of'
sen.e: As the Jodai, or castle caretaker, he was in charge of political affairs whenever Mitsunari was away.

sen.j: 朝鮮出兵に際しては、楠木正虎とともに肥前名護屋城に駐屯し、帳簿を担当。
sen.e: During the Japanese invasions of Korea, he resided with Masatora KUSUNOKI at Hizen-Nagoya-jo Castle and managed as an accountant.
During the Japanese invasions of Korea, he was stationed, along with Masatora KUSUNOKI, at Hizen-Nagoya-jo Castle as an accountant.
During the Japanese invasions of Korea, he was stationed, along with Masatora KUSUNOKI, at Hizen-Nagoya-jo Castle as an accountant.

sen.j: 1600（慶長5）年関ヶ原の戦いでは西軍に与し、正澄とともに佐和山城にいて本丸を守備するも、小早川秀秋らの猛攻に遭って半日も持たずに敗退、落城に際して正継は自刃した。
sen.e: He contributed to the Western Army during the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600 and protected the fortified castle with Masatora, but he was defeated within half a day under to furious attacks from Hideaki KOBAYAMA, and committed suicide with his sword when the falling of castle was apparent.

He fought with the Western Army during the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, defending the inner bailey of Sawayama-jo castle with Masazumi, but under Hideaki KOBAYAMA's furious attacks, the castle fell within half a day and Masatsugu committed suicide with his sword.

He fought with the Western Army during the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, defending the inner bailey of Sawayama-jo Castle with Masazumi, but under Hideaki KOBAYAMA's furious attacks, the castle fell within half a day and Masatsugu committed suicide with his sword.

sen.j: 墓所は京都市右京区の妙心寺で、当寺には正継の肖像画も所蔵されている。
sen.e: The grave site is located at Myoshin-ji Temple in Ukyo-ku, Kyoto City, and the same temple stores a portrait of Masatsugu.
His grave is located at Myoshin-ji Temple in Ukyo-ku, Kyoto City, which is also in possession of a portrait of Masatsugu.
